In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any

of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In a consultation process conducted in 2007 on behalf of the Global Environment Facility 
(GEF) Pacific Alliance for Sustainability, five Pacific developing member countries (DMCs)—the 
Cook  Islands,  Papua  New  Guinea  (PNG),  Samoa,  Tonga,  and  Vanuatu—expressed  keen 
interest in, and assigned high priority to, reducing their consumption of fossil fuels. In response, 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved regional technical assistance (TA) for Promoting 
Energy  Efficiency  in  the  Pacific  to  provide  preliminary  assistance  to  reduce  fossil  fuel 
consumption in these five DMCs through demand-side energy efficiency assessment.1 Work 
under the TA has identified a significant pipeline of activities for promoting energy efficiency. 
Implementation of this pipeline in the five DMCs will be the focus of the proposed regional 
capacity development TA. 
 
2.  An application for cofinancing was made to the GEF2 based on analysis and data 
gathered  under  the  previous  TA,  and  the  project  identification  form  was  approved  on 
10 September 2009.3 An ADB fact-finding mission undertaken between July and September 
2010 discussed the proposed TA with government and local stakeholders. An understanding 
was reached with the governments on the purpose, components, cost estimates and financing, 
and implementation arrangements of the TA. 4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Pacific DMCs are extremely vulnerable to the cost of imported fossil fuels. The Cook 
Islands, Tonga, and Vanuatu have electricity generation systems that rely almost exclusively on 
fossil fuel (diesel) power generation, and electricity tariffs across the region are very high, with 
actual residential tariffs ranging from $0.22 per kilowatt-hour in PNG to $0.46 per kilowatt-hour 
in the Cook Islands. Paying for imported fossil fuels places a major strain on local economies 
and trade balances. Pacific DMC economies are already under strong pressure to meet urgent 
national, social, development, and environmental needs, while being economically reliant on 
limited exports of uncertain value (e.g., copra), remittances from overseas, tourism, and foreign 
aid. Fossil fuels are a major cost that Pacific DMCs have little control over, and the volatility and 
high  level  of  oil-based  fossil  fuel  prices  is  a  threat  to  the  ongoing  social,  economic,  and 
environmental development and sustainability of these countries. 
 
4.  The  development  and  use  of  conventional  energy  significantly  contributes  to  the 
accumulation of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere and associated climate change impacts. 
Although  the  accumulation  of  greenhouse  gases  is  largely  the  result  of  energy  use  by 
developed countries, the high vulnerability of small islands and low-lying atolls to the impacts of 
climate change has created very strong interest in addressing the problem within Pacific DMCs. 
Hence, Pacific DMCs are among the most active countries supporting deep global greenhouse 
gas emission reductions, and one means by which they may show their tangible support is to 
manage their own greenhouse gas emissions. 
 
5.  Pacific DMCs benefit from a wide variety of projects funded by development partners in 
the  energy field.  However, most  projects  have focused  on more  visible  renewable  energy

applications,  with  only  some  sporadic  energy  efficiency  activities.5 Past  energy  efficiency 
activities (including ADB regional TA)6 have comprised studies of energy-saving potentials and 
the  provision  of  policy  and  advisory  assistance,  and  have  generally  lacked  a  tangible 
implementation focus relating to capacity building and catalyzing the deployment of energy 
efficient  appliances  and  equipment.  For  example,  the  following  have  been  undertaken:  (i) 
energy audit training and energy audits, but without a link to accessing financing mechanisms to 
implement the findings; (ii) household surveys, but without a proper energy end-use focus and 
without assembling the information into usable end-use databases; and (iii) studies of the 
potential for minimum energy performance standards and energy labeling for appliances, but 
without identified funding paths to implement findings. 
 
6.  There  have  also  been  few  efforts  to  stimulate  the  sector  using  innovative  energy 
efficiency  technologies.  Significant  potential  exists  to  catalyze  the  use  of  energy  efficient 
equipment,  including  (i)  long  lasting,  voltage-variation-tolerant  compact  fluorescent  lamps; 
(ii) long  lasting,  low-power  streetlamps,  such  as  light-emitting  diodes;  (iii)  modern  linear 
fluorescent fittings with low-loss ballasts and reflector diffusers; and (iv) high part-load efficiency 
inverter air conditioners. Finally, there has been no effort to ensure that new buildings are 
constructed to be energy efficient through practical energy efficiency provisions in applicable 
building codes. Therefore, there is large potential for implementation-focused energy efficiency 
activities. 
 
7.  Efficient energy use is compromised due to a number of factors, including (i) insufficient 
public understanding and awareness of the potential of energy efficiency initiatives; (ii) lack of 
confidence among stakeholders in energy efficiency technologies due to the limited success of 
demonstration programs; (iii) inadequate institutional capacities and technical expertise to plan, 
manage, and maintain energy efficiency programs; (iv) lack of clear energy efficiency policies, 
legislation, regulatory frameworks, and enforcement; and (v) limited political commitment and 
financial support to the sector. The project will address these limitations by prioritizing the 
establishment  of  appropriate  institutional  arrangements;  implementing  suitable  policy  and 
legislative  support;  collecting,  analyzing,  and  disseminating  energy  data  required  for 
identification  and  monitoring  of  demand-side  efficiency  improvements;  and  implementing 
national energy efficiency programs and public awareness campaigns. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The  impact  will  be  reduction  in  fossil  fuel  use  by  the  power  sector  without  a 
corresponding reduction in energy services in the five participating DMCs. The outcome will be 
that  end  consumers  use  power  efficiently  in  the  participating  countries.  Assuming 
macroeconomic conditions remain stable, the initiative will reduce the energy intensity of the 
economies in question as well as promote energy security and reductions in greenhouse gas 
emissions from the power sector. The TA will also lead to greater affordability of energy services 
for consumers. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  Through energy efficiency improvements in the residential, commercial, and government 
sectors of each country, the TA will improve the efficiency with which consumers use power. 
The TA will develop and implement (i) a comprehensive database on energy use by sector and 
appliance; (ii) energy efficiency policies and capacity building for the government and private 
sector; and (iii) national energy efficiency programs and interventions in the public lighting; 
residential  lighting;  and  residential,  private,  and  public  buildings.  Results  and  knowledge 
products will be disseminated across the region to encourage replication in other Pacific DMCs. 
To ensure that least-cost energy efficiency initiatives are selected, financial and economic 
analysis will be undertaken to compare the chosen solution to alternative renewable energy 
options and supply-side efficiency improvements, as well as to the short-run marginal cost of 
diesel power generation. Measurement targets will include simple and discounted payback 
period, marginal cost, and cost per kilowatt-hour.  The TA will be structured around five outputs. 
 
10.  Output 1: Stakeholder access to comprehensive information on energy use. This 
output will complement the analysis carried out under phase 1 (footnote 1) by conducting 
surveys  to  complete  the  picture  of  existing  and  projected  appliance  and  equipment 
characteristics, patterns of use, and useful lifetimes. The main output will be an accessible 
database of energy use by sector and major appliance category in each country. 
 
11.  Output 2: Energy efficiency practices mainstreamed into government policies and 
procedures.  This  output  will  involve  (i)  establishing  practical  and  implementable  energy 
efficiency targets and their incorporation into national energy policies and plans; (ii) suppressing 
sale and use of high-energy-consumption appliances and equipment through import regulations 
brought about by the development and enforcement of effective minimum energy performance 
standards and/or energy labeling; (iii) improving energy efficiency best practices for newly built 
residential,  commercial,  and  government  buildings,  including  the  establishment  of  simple, 
effective, and enforceable energy efficiency provisions in building codes for new buildings; (iv) 
developing and implementing training programs for local experts in undertaking energy audits 
and in providing energy efficient products and services; and (v) supporting the development of 
motivated and organized service providers that have incentives to implement energy efficiency 
activities. 
 
12.  Output 3: Energy efficiency programs implemented effectively and sustainably. As 
analyzed and piloted in phase 1 (footnote 1), this output will involve a number of tangible 
implementation initiatives, including (i) upgrading street lighting using energy efficient and long-
life technologies; (ii) providing energy efficient lighting systems to residential, commercial, and 
government buildings; (iii) undertaking energy audits in hotels and other nonresidential private 
buildings  and  subsequently  implementing  recommended  improvements  in  air-conditioning, 
lighting, refrigeration, water heating, and management schemes; and (iv) undertaking energy 
audits and subsequently implementing recommended improvements in government buildings. 
 
13.  Output 4: Information dissemination and improved public awareness. This output 
will include (i) disseminating information to public and private stakeholders on the benefits of 
energy-saving technologies and practices through public education programs, workshops, and 
media; and (ii) leveraging project benefits and information exchange beyond the participating 
DMCs using regional workshops, innovative information and communication technologies, and 
knowledge products in a usable format.

4   
14.  Output 5: Effective project management established. This output will ensure the 
program of activities is implemented on time and to budget. Significant activities under this 
output are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $12,421,545 equivalent, of which (i) $1,000,000 will be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-IV); 
(ii) $5,254,545 will be funded on a joint basis by the GEF;7 (iii) $1,000,000 will be funded on a 
joint basis by the Government of Australia;8 and (iv) $1,500,000 will be funded on a parallel 
basis by the Asian Clean Energy Fund under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility.9 
All cofinancing will be administered by ADB and will be provided on an untied grant basis. The 
five DMC governments will contribute $2,047,000 equivalent in the form of in-kind contributions 
to finance the costs of counterpart staff, office accommodation, communication, local transport, 
consultations, awareness facilitation, and other energy efficiency initiatives. Power utilities will 
contribute $1,620,000 in the form of in-kind parallel financing under outputs 3 and 4 and they 
will not act as suppliers of energy efficient equipment.10 Detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 
2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  Executing and implementing agencies. The TA will be implemented over a 4-year 
period commencing on 1 April 2011 and ending on 31 March 2015. ADB’s Pacific Department, 
through the Transport, Energy and Natural Resources Division, will serve as the executing 
agency  and  will  be  responsible  for  coordinating,  supervising,  and  implementing  all  project 
activities. The in-country implementation of this TA will be the responsibility of the following 
agencies: (i) Energy Department in the Cook Islands; (ii) Department of Petroleum and Energy 
in PNG; (iii) Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment in Samoa; (iv) Tonga Energy Road 
Map Implementation Unit, Prime Minister’s Department, in Tonga; and (v) Energy Unit, Ministry 
of Lands and Natural Resources, in Vanuatu. 
 
17.  Program  management.  A  TA  coordination  unit  will  be  set  up  within  the  Pacific 
Department and will comprise core international and administrative staff and a national program 
coordinator who will oversee day-to-day TA implementation on behalf of ADB. The unit will liaise 
with other ADB units and offices, particularly the South Pacific Subregional Office, Pacific 
Liaison and Coordination Office, and focal points in the Regional and Sustainable Development 
Department. 
 
18.  A steering committee comprising representatives from ADB and a regional organization 
will be established to allow for the transparent and robust selection of subprojects for funding. 
Clear measurement targets and decision-making criteria will be developed against which to 
select individual projects to ensure that the process of providing subsidies and/or grants to

TA coordination unit and will be procured in accordance with the ADB Procurement Guidelines 
(2010, as amended from time to time). Equipment will be turned over to the implementing 
agency upon TA completion. The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in accordance with the

19.  Consulting  services.  The  TA  will  require  191  person-months  of  international  and 
313 person-months of national consulting services (Appendix 3). ADB will engage a national 
program coordinator on an individual basis to serve for 48 person-months (based at ADB 
headquarters) to provide project and procurement management for the TA, including liaison with 
development partner activities in the Pacific DMCs. A program management consultant (firm) 
will  be  recruited  to  supply  114  person-months  of  international  and  240  person-months  of 
national consulting services to support in-country program management and implementation in 
the five DMCs. The firm will be engaged using quality- and cost-based selection evaluation on a 
90:10 basis. Short-term technical specialists will be recruited on an individual basis to provide 
77 person-months of international and 25 person-months of national consulting services. All 
consultants will be selected and engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION AND DECISION 
20.  The President recommends that the Board approve ADB administering a portion of the 
technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $5,254,545  for  Promoting  Energy 
Efficiency in the Pacific (Phase 2), to be financed on a grant basis by the Global Environment 
Facility. If the Board approves ADB administering the technical assistance, the President, acting 
under the authority delegated by the Board, will approve (i) ADB administering a portion of the 
technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis 
by the Government of Australia; (ii) ADB administering a portion of the technical assistance not 
exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Asian Clean 
Energy Fund under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility; and (iii) ADB providing the 
balance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis, for Promoting Energy 
Efficiency in the Pacific (Phase 2).

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  This appendix provides a summary of the consulting services required during technical 
assistance (TA)  implementation  and the type  of  technical  services  and/or specialist  inputs 
required (Table A3). The TA will require a total of 191 person-months of international and 
313 person-months of national consulting services. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will 
engage a national program coordinator on an individual basis for 48 person-months (based at 
ADB headquarters) to provide project and procurement management for the TA, including 
liaison with development partner activities in Pacific developing member countries (DMCs). A 
program  management  consultant  (firm)  will  be  recruited  to  supply  114  person-months  of 
international and 240 person-months of national consulting services to carry out in-country 
program management and implementation in the five participating DMCs)—the Cook Islands, 
Papua New Guinea (PNG), Samoa, Tonga, and Vanuatu. The firm will be engaged using 
quality- and cost-based selection evaluation on a 90:10 basis. Short-term technical specialists 
will be recruited on an individual basis to provide 77 person-months of international and 25 
person-months of national consulting services. All consultants will be selected and engaged by 
ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time 
to time).

B.  National Program Coordinator (individual consultant, 48 person-months) 
2.  A national program coordinator will be engaged directly by ADB to provide technical 
support  to  the  participating  countries  during  TA  implementation.  The  coordinator  will  have 
extensive  knowledge  of  internal  procedures  and  documentation  requirements,  detailed 
knowledge of contract documentation and approval procedures in ADB, as well as a sound 
understanding of both the financial and progress reporting requirements of ADB TA. A working 
knowledge of Global Environment Facility (GEF)-financed contracting would be an advantage. 
In addition, the coordinator will have a minimum of 5 years experience of working in the Pacific 
region in procurement, program administration, and team leadership. The coordinator shall also 
have  excellent  leadership  skills  and  experience  of  managing  teams  remotely.  A  working 
knowledge of energy efficiency applications will also be deemed a prerequisite. The coordinator 
will be based in ADB headquarters in Manila. The specific tasks include the following: 
(i)  take responsibility for the day-to-day administration of TA implementation; 
(ii)  liaise  closely  with  the  program  management  consultant  (consulting  firm)  to 
ensure that work planning, financial management, and program reporting are 
consistently applied using an agreed format and timelines; 
(iii)  review all draft work plans submitted by the program management consultant 
(consulting firm) and provide comments on a timely basis; 
(iv)  approve final work plans and associated budgets; 
(v)  review all contracting and procurement documentation using a no-objection basis 
from each DMC, and obtain ADB approval for these;

(vi)  initiate and hold regular coordination meetings with the program management 
consultant (consulting firm) to ensure that approvals and processing systems are 
not delaying implementation; and 
(vii)  provide  regular  updates  on  progress  of  implementation  to  ADB  on 
implementation performance, obstacles, and options for resolution. 
 
C.  Program Management Consultant (firm) 
 
3.  An  international  consulting  firm  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  to  serve  as  program 
management consultant. This firm will have responsibility for carrying out the in-country program 
management and implementation of all technical and administrative inputs on a day-to-day 
basis  in  collaboration  with  the  implementing  agencies  in  the  five  participating  DMCs.  The 
consulting firm will provide the services of (i) an international team leader and energy efficiency 
technical  expert  for  24  person-months,  (ii)  international  country-focused  energy  efficiency 
experts  for  90  person-months,  (iii)  national  country-focused  energy  efficiency  experts  for 
240 person-months to support specific in-country program management and implementation 
activities in the five DMCs.

D.  Short-Term Technical Experts (individual consultants, 102 person-months) 
7.  A number of short-term experts will be hired for a total of 102 person-months (77 person-
months for international consultants and 25 person-months for national consultants) to provide 
technical expertise on discrete project components. The experts will provide technical expertise 
in  specialist  areas  to  the  team  leader  and  energy  efficiency  technical  expert  and  to  the 
appropriate country-focused experts. The expertise required will cover (i) energy efficiency 
policy, regulation, and legislation development; (ii) appliance and equipment energy efficiency 
technical development and implementation through minimum energy performance standards, 
labeling,  and  incentives;  (iii)  energy  efficiency  requirements  in  building  codes;  (iv) energy 
efficient lighting products; (v) building energy efficiency applications and energy audits; (vi) 
energy efficiency investment and financing; (vii) energy end-use and appliance ownership and 
use  surveys  and  databases;  (viii)  market-based  approaches  to  energy  efficient  lighting, 
equipment,  and  appliances,  including  compact  fluorescent  lamps  and  light-emitting  diodes, 
refrigeration appliances, and air-conditioning; and (ix) project evaluation.
